oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Role of Britain in the Historiography of 1968:: A Review of Discourse(s)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Viol, Claus-Ulrich
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: British history
Whig history
student activism
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This article subjects standard literature on 1968 in Britain to a critical, discourse-focused reading, asking not primarily what role ’68 played in Britain, but what role Britain is allowed to play in the (international) historiography of 1968. It finds a discursive formation in historiography that revolves around divisions of presence/absence, rise/decline, extremism/moderation and original/imitation, with a narrative structure or emplotment that commonly privileges the second term of each pair as the endpoint of the story of ’68 in Britain. It also finds that there is a way to undermine the dominant discursive patterns by validating and integrating elements of subjective and collective experience and discourse into historical reconstruction and evaluation, not least in order to avoid some of the pitfalls of master narrative and national mythology.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Moving the Social; Vol. 64 (2020): '1968' in Britain; 81-101
